May 6, 2012: Fiction
THE INNOCENT, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A hitman who has
become a target of the government rescues a teenage girl whose parents have
been murdered and who may be at the center of a dangerous conspiracy.
THE WITNESS, by Nora Roberts. (Putnam, $27.95.) A programmer hides from the
Russian mob in the Ozarks.
CALICO JOE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A pitcher beans a promising
rookie, ending both their careers; years later, the pitcher’s son brings them together.
UNNATURAL ACTS, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $26.95.) The New York lawyer
Stone Barrington becomes involved in the family problems of a billionaire hedge
fund manager.
GUILTY WIVES, by James Patterson and David Ellis. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Four
friends in Monte Carlo for a luxurious girls’ vacation find themselves in prison,
accused of a crime.
THE LOST YEARS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $26.99.) A biblical
scholar who made an amazing discovery is murdered.
WHAT DOESN'T KILL YOU, by Iris Johansen. (St. Martin's, $27.99.) A Hong Kong
woman who works for the C.I.A. searches for a deadly formula while she fights to
save her son.
COME HOME, by Lisa Scottoline. (St. Martin’s, $27.99.) A woman joins with her
estranged former stepdaughter to investigate the possible murder of her ex-
husband.
SACRé BLEU, by Christopher Moore. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Vincent van
Gogh’s friends in the 19th-century Parisian art world investigate his suicide.
THE SHOEMAKER'S WIFE, by Adriana Trigiani. (Harper/HarperCollins, $26.99.)
Childhood sweethearts in turn-of-the-20th-century Italy meet again in America.
THE LIMPOPO ACADEMY OF PRIVATE DETECTION, by Alexander McCall Smith.
(Pantheon, $24.95.) The 13th novel in the No. 1 Ladies’ Detective Agency series.
BETRAYAL, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte Press, $28.) A happy and successful
Hollywood director discovers that someone is embezzling large sums of her money.
STAY CLOSE, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $27.95.) A disappearance in Atlantic City
brings together three frustrated people whose lives were once connected.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) After a
colossal battle, the Seven Kingdoms face new threats; Book 5 of "A Song of Ice and
Fire."
Non-Fiction
DRIFT, by Rachel Maddow. (Crown, $25.) America’s path to war has become too
easy, with excessive power ceded to the executive branch, the MSNBC host
argues.
LET’S PRETEND THIS NEVER HAPPENED, by Jenny Lawson. (Amy
Einhorn/Putnam, $25.95.) A blogger recalls her unusual upbringing.
IMAGINE, by Jonah Lehrer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) An account of the
science of creativity argues that it is not a gift but a thought process that can be
learned.
THE PRESIDENTS CLUB, by Nancy Gibbs and Michael Duffy. (Simon &
Schuster, $32.5.) Two journalists examine the relationships between sitting
presidents and their predecessors.
THE BIG MISS, by Hank Haney. (Crown Archetype, $26.) The golf coach’s
memoir describes his six eventful years with Tiger Woods.
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur based on 40 interviews with Jobs conducted over
two years.
MRS. KENNEDY AND ME, by Clint Hill with Lisa McCubbin. (Gallery Books, $26.)
Recollections of the Secret Service agent assigned to guard Jacqueline Kennedy.
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail.
THE POWER OF HABIT, by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $28.) A Times
reporter’s account of the science behind how we form, and break, habits.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of
"The O'Reilly Factor" recounts the heart-stopping events surrounding the
assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
A NATURAL WOMAN, by Carole King. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A memoir by the
songwriter, singer and activist whose 1971 album “Tapestry” remained in the No. 1
position on the Billboard chart for 15 weeks.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
TRICKLE DOWN TYRANNY, by Michael Savage. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99.)
The radio host denounces President Obama’s domestic and foreign policies as
tyranny.
AMERICAN SNIPER, by Chris Kyle with Scott McEwen and Jim DeFelice.
